etymologies: mid 16th century (as a legal term meaning ‘formally offer a plea or evidence, or money to discharge a debt’, also as a noun denoting such an offer): from Old French tendre, from Latin tendere ‘to stretch, hold forth’ (see tend)

examples.text: he tendered his resignation as leader

definitions: make a formal written offer to carry out work, supply goods, or buy land, shares, or another asset for a stated fixed price

examples.text: firms of interior decorators have been tendering for the work

shortDefinitions: make formal written offer to carry out work

definitions: make a formal offer giving (a stated fixed price)

examples.text: what price should we tender for a contract?

shortDefinitions: formally offer stated fixed price for carrying out work etc.

definitions: an offer to carry out work, supply goods, or buy land, shares, or another asset at a stated fixed price

examples.text: we invited tenders for up to three more frigates
being government land, it was sold by tender

shortDefinitions: offer to carry out work, supply goods

etymologies: Middle English: from Old French tendre, from Latin tener ‘tender, delicate’

definitions: showing gentleness and concern or sympathy

examples.text: he was being so kind and tender
be tender of a lady's reputation

definitions: (of food) easy to cut or chew; not tough
(of a part of the body) sensitive to pain

examples.text: the pale, tender skin of her forearm

definitions: (of a plant) easily injured by severe weather and therefore needing protection

examples.text: pelargoniums are colorful but tender plants

shortDefinitions: (of plant) easily injured by severe weather and therefore needing protection

examples.text: the issue of conscription was a particularly tender one
at the tender age of five

definitions: (of a ship) leaning or readily inclined to roll in response to the wind.
shortDefinitions: (of ship) leaning or readily inclined to roll in response to wind

etymologies: late Middle English (in the sense ‘attendant, nurse’): from tend or shortening of attender (see attend)

definitions: a boat used to ferry people and supplies to and from a ship.
shortDefinitions: boat used to ferry people and supplies to and from ship

definitions: a railcar coupled to a steam locomotive to carry fuel and water.
shortDefinitions: railcar coupled to steam locomotive to carry fuel and water

definitions: a person who looks after someone else or a machine or place

examples.text: Alexei signaled to one of the engine tenders

notes.text: usually in combination or with modifier

shortDefinitions: person who looks after someone else or machine or place
